This Is Graham Hovey, sending along another ml radio Letter from
Italy under a Home dateline. These programs are produced for the
National Association of Educational Broadcasters with the cooperation
of Radio Italians.
Before I came to Italy a couple of months ago friends told me
that this time I might find a strong anti-American feeling, particularly
in Rome. They said I should be prepared for this i that Italy, and
especially Home, might not be as friendly and accommodating as I had
found them on previous visits.
That anti-Americanism may exist. It probably does exist in some
circles and in some measure. After all, the Italians have experienced
what one might call two American invasions in the last ten years. The
first one was military and the second one was everything else: a tourist
invasion; an invasion of American economic experts in the Marshall Plan
days; invasions of Congressional investigating teams; and what some would
call a kind of cultural Invasion that includes everything from movies
and Coca Cola and dinger sewing machines to artists and writers and
visiting professors.
Bo, I say, that anti-Americanism may exist. But I haven't found
it. The only major evidence of anti-American feeling I have seen was
that displayed in the student demonstrations and riots over the Trieste
violence, which I talked about in a previous Letter from Italy. And
the British caught that attack worse than we did. In any event. It
soon died down and the anti-American part of it was quickly forgotten.
what I have found in Italy that directly concerns Americans is
something that I believe is more Important; has more longrange signifies*#
canoe than these surface evidences of anti-Americanism that I was
supposed to find.
